com.meteorcode.pathway.model

Class Move

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.meteorcode.pathway.model.Event
      • com.meteorcode.pathway.model.Move

  • public class Move
extends Event
    An Event that represents an Entity's attempt to move from one Tile to another.

    ==How to Use==

    A Move provides the following Payload when inspected by a Property: - "who": Entity - the Entity that is attempting the move. - "to": Tile - the Tile that "who" wants to move to. - "from": Tile - the Tile that "who" currently occupies - "location": Tile - the Tile that originated this Event (should be the same as "from")

    Note that when a Move evaluates itself, it will check if the target tile is occupied(). If the tile is occupied, the Move will invalidate() itself. This shouldn't make a difference, as the pumping Context has already poppedit off the EventStack, and will just quietly not take place. However, if anything cares about validity at that point, do note that the Move will be invalid.

    This is provided primarily for convenience, and represents essentially the simplest possible interpretation of the idea of a character or monster moving from one game grid square to another. If your game's rule-set has more complex rules for moving, you have several options:

    1. Add Properties to the game that watch for Move events that match some criterion, and invalidate() them if they are illegal, or patch their payload with some additional data. This is probably the Right Thing (I might even go as far as to refer to it as "idiomatic Pathway". Note that Move stores its data (original tile, target tile, entity that's moving) in a Payload rather than as fields in the Move class specifically so that you can interact with Moves like any other

    2. Extend Move with different subclasses representing the different types of Move in your game's rule set. This is also the Right Thing, if the circumstances call for it.

    3. Completely ignore our Move class and write your own. You should really only have to do this if you aren't using our Grid/Time system at all. Otherwise, I'd recommend avoiding this, if possible.

    • Method Detail

      • evalEvent

        public void evalEvent()
        Description copied from class: Event

        The method that is called to actually perform the thing done by an Event. Should be called as part of the event loop, when an event is finally... you know, evented.

        NOTE that this occurs after the event has been propagated, and also NOTE that this method will *not* be called on an invalidated Event. (Event code shouldn't have to worry whether or not they're invalid)

        Specified by:
        evalEvent in class Event
